Zero-knowledge proofs are no longer just technical tools; they‚Äôre now valuable and tradeable assets.
 
Succinct (@SuccinctLabs) is building the future of zero-knowledge computing. If Bitcoin has miners, Ethereum has Stakers, Succinct has ‚ÄúPROVERS‚Äù

Think of it as a global compute network where anyone can request and access cryptographic proofs on demand.
 
üîé  Key Highlights You Need To Know:

‚úÖ Succinct is Making Zero-Knowledge (ZK) Simple for Everyone:

Old ZK tech was hard and highly specialized‚Äîlike coding in assembly language. Also, only cryptography PhDs could use it effectively. With SP1, Succinct makes ZK easy‚Äîjust write normal code.

‚úÖ  How Does SP1 Work?

SP1 is a next-gen zkVM that‚Äôs 10x faster than other solutions. It can prove the correct execution of any software. This means:

üëâ Game outcomes can be proven fair
üëâ DeFi transactions can be verified
üëâ AI outputs can be audited for honesty
 
‚úÖ $PROVE token for The Prover Network

üî∏ Developers pay for proofs using $PROVE tokens

üî∏ GPU operators compete in global ‚Äúproof contests‚Äù to win the task which drives:

üëâ  Competition ‚Üí Lower proof costs  
üëâ Infrastructure growth ‚Üí More GPUs worldwide
üëâ  It mirrors how Bitcoin mining built a global hardware network‚Äîbut for ZK computing
 
Why It Matters?

üî∏ Succinct is turning ZK proofs into mainstream infrastructure

üî∏ Makes trustless, verifiable computing accessible to all developers‚Äînot just cryptography experts

üî∏ Opens the door for scalable, secure, and decentralized apps across industries

Disclaimer - we have invested in Succinct so please don‚Äôt forget to do your research.

MY $HIMS EARNINGS PREVIEW 

Hims has been through it. First came the rip on the $NVO partnership. Then came a 35% collapse when that deal fell apart. Now it‚Äôs clawed back near the highs, with short interest still hovering above 30%. Everyone‚Äôs waiting to see if the next leg is a squeeze or a flush.

But what‚Äôs getting lost in the noise is the business underneath. While all eyes are on GLP-1s and semaglutide drama, the core of what Hims is building isn‚Äôt about any one drug. It‚Äôs a full-stack digital healthcare platform. 2.4M subs. 95% recurring revenue. 85% retention. ARPU up 50% YoY. And it‚Äôs profitable.

They‚Äôve vertically integrated fulfillment, pharmacy, diagnostics, and compounding -- turning D2C care into a subscription engine, not a transactional marketplace. The GLP-1 headlines are a distraction. They‚Äôre already shifting toward liraglutide, oral options, and custom formulations in markets like Canada, where patent windows are opening.

The bigger risk isn‚Äôt $NVO. It‚Äôs $AMZN. Prime members now get One Medical for $9/month -- 24/7 virtual care, in-person visits, and same-day delivery in major metros. Amazon doesn‚Äôt need to win on product. It wins on price, bundling, and logistics -- weapons most healthtech players can‚Äôt match.

But that doesn‚Äôt mean Hims is finished. In every consumer category Big Tech enters -- music, streaming, hardware -- people assume the pure-plays are toast. But the ones that know their audience, build real product depth, and keep executing‚Ä¶ survive. Sometimes they even lead -- look at $SPOT & $NFLX. Hims may not win on scale, but brand and trust matter in healthcare -- and they‚Äôve carved that lane better than anyone.

Heading into earnings, my eyes are on one thing: margins. After peaking at 82% in late 2023, they‚Äôve fallen three straight quarters to 77%, wiping out nearly two years of efficiency gains.

For Hims, margin is the cleanest signal of platform leverage. This isn‚Äôt just about top-line growth -- it‚Äôs about whether unit economics are compounding as the business scales. When the engine‚Äôs running, margins expand. When they contract, it raises questions about moat and durability.

This trend needs to reverse. Last quarter‚Äôs hit came from compounded mix, but if vertical integration is working -- cutting out middlemen and absorbing fulfillment costs -- we should see stabilization or even a bounce. That‚Äôs the signal I‚Äôm watching.
$GOOGL IS NOW THE MOST PROFITABLE COMPANY IN THE WORLD WITH $116B IN ANNUAL NET INCOME

MY $AMD EARNINGS PREVIEW: WHY THIS QUARTER MATTERS MORE THAN EVER

I think we‚Äôre about to see the most important earnings print in AMD‚Äôs history -- not because Q2 will be flawless, but because it‚Äôs the clearest test yet of whether AMD‚Äôs AI transformation has teeth. The business is evolving fast. And the way the market re-rates this name over the next 12‚Äì18 months will hinge on how AMD threads the needle between growth and profitability at a platform scale.

Margins Will Dip, but That‚Äôs Not the Point

Let‚Äôs be clear: margins will still be under pressure. Gross margins could fall to 52% due to a mix of high-bandwidth memory costs, 5nm packaging, and ROCm ecosystem investments. That‚Äôs to be expected when you‚Äôre ramping a next-gen AI platform from scratch. But underneath that margin compression is something far more important -- AMD is starting to price like a leader, scale like a leader, and land contracts like a leader. 

From Underdog to Platform Contender

The MI350 pricing bump from $15K to $25K is a flashing signal to the street. This is no longer a ‚Äúbudget‚Äù option to $NVDA Blackwell stack. It‚Äôs a viable, competitive product with real performance credentials, being adopted at scale by hyperscalers like $ORCL and major inference users like $TSLA. And it's backed by a growing ROCm ecosystem with better compiler support, Hugging Face integrations, and day-one $META LLaMA 4 readiness. When you combine that with the fact that AMD is already taking CPU share from $INTC on both the client and server side, and layering in rack-scale design capabilities via the ZT Systems acquisition, the strategic picture becomes clearer: AMD is building a full-stack, disaggregated alternative to the vertically integrated AI infra model.

The Optionality Is What‚Äôs Explosive

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm more excited about AMD than I‚Äôve ever been. But because the optionality in the model is exploding. GPU revenue could exceed $4B this year. AI as a % of total revenue is rising. The data center segment is approaching 50% of total business. And while consensus still models a trough in Q2, the ramp into H2 looks like the beginning of a multi-year compounding engine -- especially if AMD nails the MI355X launch and reopens MI308X shipments to China.

A Re-Rating Moment in the Making?

This quarter is less about the numbers and more about whether the market finally accepts AMD as more than a challenger. If management guides Q3 revenue above $8B and shows any signs of margin re-expansion, the market will have to start pricing this company as a legitimate AI infrastructure platform -- one that offers hyperscalers flexibility, pricing leverage, and a non-CUDA path to LLM scaling. That shift in perception, combined with already rising demand for MI-series chips, is what could justify a move toward $200+ over the next 12 months.

Bottom line: I don‚Äôt expect a melt-up on earnings. The stock is extended, RSI is hot, and any in-line guide could lead to a short-term fade. But this is the first time in AMD‚Äôs history where every part of the business -- CPUs, GPUs, software, system design -- is moving in the same direction.

In recent years, all survey response rates have collapsed (chart). This is true for a political survey, a business customer satisfaction survey, or a government economic survey, which have seen respondents refuse or become uninterested in participating. This leads to ever larger error rates.

The trend in the chart is not reversing, so expect it to get worse.

(My take: technology has made surveys easy to conduct, and way too many exist. So they lose their appeal. Not helping is the perception that political polls are biased and highly inaccurate, which has "poisoned the well" for all surveys. Furthermore, social media now provides people with an outlet to express their opinions. Filling out surveys, no matter their intention, has lost its appeal.) 
---
See how the University of Michigan Consumer Confidence Survey has been poisoned by partisanship.  Three years ago, the Federal Reserve proclaimed this one of its most important indicators.

The era of surveys is over. Unfortunately, surveys are the backbone of economic data. What is now required is to measure actual output, not samplings or opinions about it.

In the case of the jobs market, the solution can be to connect with the IRS databases and obtain real-time withholding data for every job in the country.

BLS statisticians and IRS employees will likely agree and then drone on about the cost. 

The cost can be free.  @elonmusk  tried to do it for free, and DC rebuffed him. If you don't like him, call Alex Karp @PalantirTech, CEO of Palantir, I'll bet you can talk him into doing it for free. Others might say the same.

Government statisticians seem to have as their goal flawless execution of a flawed process. This has to change.

@chamath @NickTimiraos  @BobEUnlimited

How "exercised" was Trump about the Fed today?

Daily chart back to the beginning of the year of all of Trump's Fed-related "truths."

Today was a record, three times the old record.

Did Trump give us a "tell" about the coming payroll report, and everyone on Wall Street (including me) missed it?
---
Here are Trump's three Fed-related "truths" in the 25 hours before the payroll report.

In my subjective opinion, he was more strident and harsher than usual in his criticism of Powell.

This is especially the case for the two "truths" this morning, in the two hours before the release, when he could have seen the full report.

WITH HINDSIGHT, it does read like him lashing out against Powell, blaming him for a weak payroll report that was not yet released.

Some ask what‚Äôs my Financial Road Map doing now they the $spx is below the 8/21day

Get my #1 options idea every week:

t3live.com/ppo

#1. $spx below 8/21 day the active account becomes MORE active (more Day Trades)

#2 not many swing long trades now. 

#3. Less risk on so BOX holds less and does less

#4 option account gets more busy- risk premium paid.   Higher Vix.  Sell some premium and play options in case spots don‚Äôt work 

#5 401k keeps monthly flows a corrective phase Helps average cost 

#6 529 keeps monthly flow as a corrective phase helps average cost for college 

#7 BOS is in full cash and starts 4%-5% off highs so might come into play again. We only did two this year 

# 8 whole life in two years is 20 years in. Nice cash value building and death benefit

The ATAC Credit-On/Credit-Off Index (ticker: JOJO) is a tactical index that switches between long-term US Treasuries and high-yield ‚Äújunk‚Äù corporate bonds each week, based on a signal comparing the recent performance of US utilities stocks and the broader equity market.

When utilities outperform, the index moves into the safety of Treasuries (‚Äújunk-off‚Äù); when the broad market is strong, it rotates into riskier high-yield debt (‚Äúcredit-on‚Äù), aiming to capture gains but avoid big drawdowns.

As of the latest update, the index is ‚Äújunk-off‚Äù‚Äîso right now, it‚Äôs positioned defensively in Treasuries instead of high-yield bonds.

This approach is designed to provide investors with a dynamic allocation depending on risk signals from the stock market, and you can see from the chart that it‚Äôs delivered strong cumulative returns since inception, up about 483%.
Also, let‚Äôs remember markets don‚Äôt tend to crash until margin debt begins to decline.

The US will soon require international visitors to pay a $250 "visa integrity fee" in addition to existing visa costs.

The fee only applies to visitors who are required to obtain nonimmigrant visas (of which there were nearly 11 million in 2024).

However, the fee is reimbursed after the trip is over (assuming the traveler complied with their visa conditions).

Good idea?

Two months later, that number is down 2.2 percentage points to 4.4%.
